plants.name: Magnolia Ã— soulangeana
plants.description: A hybrid deciduous magnolia known for its large, fragrant, tulip-shaped flowers that bloom in early spring before the leaves appear. It is popular in temperate gardens and parks.
plants.location: Temperate regions of North America, Europe, and Asia
plants.funFact: Saucer magnolia flowers often appear before the leaves, creating a spectacular floral display that signals the arrival of spring.

plants.name: Eschscholzia californica
plants.description: A hardy wildflower native to the western United States that produces vibrant cup-shaped flowers. It is drought-tolerant and adapts well to dry, sandy soils.
plants.funFact: California poppies close their petals at night and during cold or windy weather, protecting their reproductive organs.

plants.name: Rhododendron spp.
plants.description: A genus comprising many species and cultivars that bloom profusely in spring, bearing clusters of bell-shaped flowers. They thrive in acidic soils and shaded spots.
plants.location: Worldwide in temperate and subtropical regions
plants.funFact: Rhododendrons attract pollinators like bees and hummingbirds, and some species are adapted to specific altitudes in mountainous regions.

plants.name: Callistemon citrinus
plants.description: An Australian native shrub notable for its bright red, brush-shaped flower spikes resembling a bottlebrush. It blooms mainly in spring and is popular in warm temperate gardens.
plants.bloomingSeason: Spring (September to November in Southern Hemisphere, around April in Northern Hemisphere cultivation)
plants.location: Australia; cultivated in subtropical gardens worldwide
plants.funFact: The unique bottlebrush flowers are adapted to bird pollination, with nectar feeding birds attracted to their vivid colors and shape.
